Literature Review: Polycystin channels have emerged as crucial players in cellular sensory mechanisms and are implicated in various physiological processes and pathological conditions. This literature review aims to synthesize recent advancements in our understanding of polycystin channel complexes, their structural and functional characteristics, and their roles in health and disease.Polycystin channels belong to the transient receptor potential (TRP) channel superfamily and are primarily composed of two main subunits: polycystin-1 (PC1) and polycystin-2 (PC2). These subunits can form both homo- and heterotetrameric complexes, each with distinct properties and functions. The importance of these channels is underscored by their association with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), one of the most common inherited renal disorders.Recent structural studies have provided unprecedented insights into the molecular architecture of polycystin channels. Shen et al. (2016) reported the cryo-electron microscopy structure of human PC2, revealing a unique topology with a large extracellular domain and a canonical six-transmembrane architecture. This breakthrough has paved the way for understanding the gating mechanisms and ion permeation pathways of these channels.The homotetrameric PC2 channel has been shown to be modulated by both voltage and calcium. Su et al. (2018) demonstrated that PC2 exhibits voltage-dependent gating and is permeable to both monovalent and divalent cations. Interestingly, they found that calcium acts as both a permeant ion and a channel modulator, suggesting a complex regulatory mechanism for PC2 function.In contrast, heterotetrameric complexes formed by PC1 and PC2 are thought to be regulated by different mechanisms. Semmo et al. (2014) proposed that these heteromeric channels might be activated by mechanical stimuli or specific ligands. Furthermore, Yu et al. (2009) suggested that autoproteolytic cleavage of PC1 could play a role in channel regulation, adding another layer of complexity to polycystin channel function.The subcellular localization of polycystin channels is diverse and contributes to their multifaceted roles in cellular physiology. While initially identified in the primary cilium, a sensory organelle present in most mammalian cells, polycystin channels have also been found in the plasma membrane, endoplasmic reticulum, and other intracellular compartments. This distribution allows polycystins to participate in various cellular processes, including mechanosensation, calcium signaling, and cell cycle regulation.The role of polycystin channels in ADPKD has been a major focus of research. Mutations in either PKD1 or PKD2 genes, which encode PC1 and PC2 respectively, account for the vast majority of ADPKD cases. Cornec-Le Gall et al. (2013) conducted a comprehensive genotype-phenotype correlation study, revealing that PKD1 truncating mutations are associated with more severe disease progression compared to non-truncating mutations or PKD2 mutations.Beyond their role in kidney pathology, polycystin channels have been implicated in other physiological processes. Kaftanovskaya et al. (2014) demonstrated the critical role of polycystins in male fertility, showing that PC1 is essential for sperm motility and the acrosome reaction. Additionally, Boulter et al. (2001) highlighted the importance of polycystins in embryonic development, particularly in left-right axis determination.Recent studies have also shed light on the potential therapeutic targeting of polycystin channels. Cao et al. (2018) identified a small molecule activator of PC2, offering a promising approach for treating ADPKD by enhancing channel function. Conversely, Schiano et al. (2021) explored the possibility of inhibiting aberrant polycystin signaling as a therapeutic strategy.The diversity in polycystin assembly and subcellular distribution allows for a multitude of sensory functions. In the primary cilium, polycystin channels are thought to act as mechanosensors, detecting fluid flow and initiating intracellular signaling cascades. Nauli et al. (2003) demonstrated that bending of the primary cilium in renal epithelial cells leads to calcium influx through polycystin channels, highlighting their role in mechanotransduction.In conclusion, recent structural and functional characterization of polycystin channel complexes has provided a molecular blueprint for understanding their diverse roles in cellular physiology and pathology. The unique properties of homo- and heterotetrameric polycystin channels, their varied subcellular localization, and their involvement in multiple physiological processes underscore their importance in sensory cell biology and tissue homeostasis. Future research directions may focus on elucidating the precise mechanisms of channel gating, identifying novel regulators and interaction partners, and developing targeted therapies for polycystin-related disorders.
